utterances.utterance: Is Roseanne the Archie Bunker of the 21st century?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I kind of feel this show is like the All in the Family, it has that feeling and that even if you disagree with Roseanne, you still like the character.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: But you are calling Roseanne Barr a racist.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I didn't say that.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: No, but that is a big criticism of that character in that show, Archie Bunker levied heavily.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, but the Jefferson's were his neighbors.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They were moving on up. But I loved the Jefferson's.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Wasn't that a great show?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I love Red Fox.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What did voters think about President Trump after the Stormy Daniels 60 Minutes interview? Find out when the Five returns.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Welcome back. Teflon Don, a new poll says President Trump is weathering the Stormy Daniels scandal just fine. A Politico morning consult survey conducted after Daniels' 60 Minutes interview suggests that her revelations are unlikely to change Trump's political standing. The President's approval rating, 42 percent this week has barely budged from 44 percent last week. This isn't a new phenomenon. Bill Clinton's approval ratings remained fairly steady during the Monica Lewinsky scandal in 1988 as you see here. Dana, could you imagine how much better President Trump's approval ratings if the media wasn't constantly trying to call him a racist, traitor, and mentally unstable cheater?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I know a little something about the media, Republican Presidents and the media and approval ratings.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Down with the Republican Presidents because they keep on getting reelected.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think one of the reasons I think that it has stayed steady here is Bill Clinton effect. As we said yesterday and today, it showed Bill Clinton actually benefited over the year of the constant attention on the Lewinsky issue. He goes up in the polls. And then he goes on to have a pretty good popularity rating all the way through until the end in 2000, which didn't help Al Gore all but well. The other thing is President Trump hasn't tweeted about her at all, and I think that has probably helped him. Because the left loves when he treats about something and they can stew on it a little bit more.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Don't jinx it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think if they starve the story of more oxygen, it probably ends up going away a little bit. But it's not like it's helping him and his approval ratings are going up. It's not hurting him.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think President Trump would love those Bill Clinton approval level ratings. Greg, even the CNN poll, which they had out earlier this week had him pretty high up, almost at a year-long high, the high 40s. So is it not working, the negative onslaught?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Because CNN has changed its programming. It's actually a stripper pole, not a normal poll.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They're like the weather channel, it is all stormy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What's interesting about CNN is that if we remember, CNN elected Donald Trump. They were the first to devote so much time to him at the expense of others. They really put him out there. And I feel like they might be reelecting Donald Trump by pushing this scandal too much because it's creating rebound sympathy for Melania and for the White House in general. I don't know if that's true yet, but it could happen. But Donald Trump, I think the most Americans are like carnival food. If you are at the fairground and you're about to order something and somebody says you know that's fattening, and you go, I factored that into my decision when I am buying this giant bowl of soft serve ice cream. I understand what I am getting. Two scoops. Because reality TV and tabloids, you know more about Trump's character than the previous six Presidents combined. So you just know this when you factored in, I don't know how it's going to affect him negatively.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So what do you think about the theory that the harsher the media is towards President Trump, the more it rallies his supporters and the more they dig in. And the approval ratings stay pretty steady.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, I don't think that's it is impacting the numbers. The good news for Trump if that's what you're saying. Trump's numbers are still worse for any President this stage of his Presidency in modern history.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Depends on what poll, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, that may be. I'll leave that to you and Greg. But I think that what's interesting to me is, is that when you look at the poll numbers, it's like 56 of Americans believe what Stormy Daniels had to say. And by the way, I was surprised at this, 35 percent say they believe that the threat that she described on 60 Minutes is credible. But what's really striking to me is when you ask people, well, what about the women involved. So as I said, about a high percentage of Americans think Stormy Daniels is telling the truth, not President Trump. But among Republicans, it's 45 percent of Republican women who now believe Stormy Daniels. So they are not necessarily shifting away from Trump, but it does I think some damage to people who believe in the leader of the free world, our country, being an honest, forthcoming, moral person. And I have got to think that erodes. I have to think that's not helpful.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, I think, Kimberly, this isn't one of these stories, the Stormy Daniels story that people are talking about over the water cooler, at dinner, or at breakfast, or in the lunchroom. This is not really high up on the American priority list.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Unless your initials are CNN.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yeah, I just think because it didn't -- it really kind of over promised, under delivered. In television, that's always a mistake. People were talking about may be this revelation, that revelation. There really wasn't. And what Greg said, that we know this type of thing has happened before with him, this is prior to him being President. It goes way back. It wasn't in the Oval Office. It wasn't while he was President, during his term, etcetera. Stormy has this name because she is a porn star, OK.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: She ran for office.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Exactly. And this was a one-off event. And I don't even know why it's getting so much air time. There are other things that are more significant.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think it is the money. It's the payoff for the silence. I think if the Wall Street Journal had not run that story in January, then we wouldn't even know her name.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Every time you do a settlement, there is an NDA. It is like a followed by a b in the alphabet.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I knew that story before that. I always thought this was just understood.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: This had been bubbling up in the...

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You have to keep in mind, I don't know, you guys seem very happy at the moment but let me tell you something. If there is a finding that in fact, Michael Cohen made this payment, I think just a few days before the election, there is big trouble brewing in terms of federal election law. Remember John Edwards.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right. We will follow that as the facts come out. Ahead, there's a big battle brewing in this country over two hot topics, sanctuary cities and the Second Amendment, President Trump now weighing in, his reaction next.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: President Trump is weighing in on the two hot topics we discussed yesterday, the Second Amendment and the debate over sanctuary cities. This morning, the President defended the right to bear arms, tweeting, "the Second Amendment will never be repealed as much as Democrats would like to see this happen, and despite the words yesterday of Former Supreme Court Justice Stevens, no way. We need more Republicans in 2018 and must always hold the Supreme Court." Juan, did the Former Justice Democrats a disservice by suggesting repeal of the Second Amendment is the real goal.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I saw in the polling, preparing for this segment, that about 20 percent of the public wants it repealed. And there's an argument to be made. I am fully capable of making it, that I don't think everybody should have a gun because we have a militia waiting to form to take on the U.S. government. That would be a futile act. But if you are asking about the politics of it, the reaction among Democrats, they think what raise this. That just feeds into Republican anger at these young people. And I was discussing with Greg yesterday, the picture, which is a fake picture of the young woman tearing up the constitution. It just plays right into that. It is not helpful for people who say and still the polls are very clear, Americans want the Second Amendment modified, they want it limited.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right. Kimberly, if you were a Republican candidate and you basically had a tough race, I think the first thing you would do is say Democrat, do you agree with, John Paul Stevens that we should repeal the Second Amendment and try to get them on record early on.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Absolutely. Thank you so much, debate team.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: And that's what you would do. Literally put them in a tough spot, little squeeze play on there and say, OK, let's see, see if you will box yourself in on this positioning. I agree with Juan. Juan, I appreciate your thoughtfulness and your honesty in this exact moment in time.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Because he is right. This is not helpful to the Democrats and Liberals. I think it is inordinately helpful to Republicans because it is so far off the realm of reality of what could happen that they lose any kind of credibility. If you are there against the wall here and you want to literally take away the number two out of the first ten, the bill of rights, you are in trouble. It's not going to happen, period.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: The other thing that President Trump did in the tweet, Greg, is he now not only talking about the Second Amendment, but he brings up the other most important issue to conservatives, which is the Supreme Court, it is a twofer tweet.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. He knows what he's doing. The left handed him the adult authority. Once you hear let's repeal the Second Amendment, the nation tilts due to all the eye rolling. If you want every American to buy a gun, simply say they can't have one. And I think what's also happening to a lot of people is you are just seeing the Trojan horse be exposed. This is not the kind of progress that gun-control zealots want. They prefer the Trojan horse of sensible gun laws in which to usher in a larger ideological push and agenda. We just want bump stocks. That's all we want.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right. It does take it away, Jesse. Like it does - - I wouldn't be paranoid if everyone wasn't against me type of thing. So for people who are supporting the Second Amendment, if they say, "You're trying to take away our guns." Like, "No, we're not." "Yes, you are." If you look at John Paul Stevens, like --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: In the newspaper, you're saying that. So if I were Mitch McConnell or Paul Ryan, I would put it to a vote. I would throw it out and I'd say, "Do you think the Second Amendment should be repealed?" And I'd make every senator and House member --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's nice.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- have to vote on it. And then, like Kimberly said, squeeze them, put them in a box. And then I'd run ads against all the people that didn't support it. I mean, this poll's crazy: 39 percent of Democrats want to repeal the Second Amendment? I mean, that is insanity, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wait, can I --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That is pure lunacy.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: They called my house, and I told them. I'm for it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I know.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The polls aren't stats. You know that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You know why? Because I don't think most of those people even know what the Second Amendment is.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But I think if there was a debate, it would probably change. But do you guys want to do the other topic?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Let me just quickly say I don't -- go ahead. You've gotten upset. Go ahead.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I'm not upset.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Why are you so upset?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: She's ticklish. But I was going to say --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- you know what? If you ask me ==

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I was about to do it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: If you say -- if you asked me, I would say honestly yes, I'm very upset by the guns and the killing going on in the country. And if you're going to say, "I'm going to vote against you because of that," I'd say what Jesse and all of you said.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You don't have a firearm, Juan. I mean, I don't think that's the smartest idea. Everyone is just going to come to her house.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: They're going to kill me?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, Juan. If you -- if you give up all your guns and the bad guys get them, and then they just go rob people.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But that's -- the strawman argument is that if you are for the Second Amendment, you are also not upset over gun violence.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: That's just totally erroneous. And yes. Hello.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: OK, producers, do we have time for the second one?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Oh, my gosh.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: We do. Two people will be called on. Kimberly, prepare yourself.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Thank you, darling.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: President Trump also tweeting this morning about the sanctuary city issue. He said: "My administration stands in solidarity with the brave citizens in Orange County defending their rights against California's illegal and unconstitutional sanctuary policies. California's sanctuary laws release known dangerous criminals into communities across the state. All citizens have the right to be protected by federal law and strong borders."

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Amen. Can I get an amen and can I get a witness? Jesse?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Hallelujah.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Hallelujah.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Praise the lord.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I just think this is an example of President Trump winning. These are two great issues for him. He's seizing the moment and the opportunity. He's saying obey the law, leave the laws on the books, whether as it relates to the Constitution. Protect the Constitution with the Second Amendment, and let's obey the law as it relates to immigration and sanctuary cities. So two very strong points for him, especially coming on the heels of this whole, like, Stormy Daniels nonsense. Which shows it didn't resonate at all in the polls whatsoever, and he's back to business. So I like the focus here.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Do you think demonizing immigrants, which is what this is about --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, Juan. No, it's not.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's what it's about.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: No, it's not.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And secondly, and saying, "I don't really care. I made some promises about gun control when I had my meeting on TV, but then I turned my -- turned around after I met with the NRA." Do you think that helps him? I don't think so.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I give the last word to Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I think what helps him is what got him elected, which is the nexus of all these law and order issues coming together. You know, what Celsius (ph) was to Obama, is what security and trunk, the border, foreign policy, or the policing. And the metaphor I go back to with the sanctuary cities, it's the freeloader, the creature that exists as long as other people do their jobs. You cannot steal cable unless your neighbor has it. So you can't have a sanctuary city unless everybody else is being a law-abiding citizen. So that's why it's immoral and it's wrong and it must be stopped.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You have a ten-second answer?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes. Juan, 80 percent of the American people are against funding sanctuary cities.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: A poll!

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Not because they all hate immigrants. This is because they want, as Greg said, law and order.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right. I'm going to tease now. After the break, we have breaking news about the secretary of the Veterans Affairs Administration. OK. I'm not reading it. We'll be right back.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: This is a FOX News alert. Another shake-up to President Trump's cabinet. The president just announcing that he is replacing Veterans Affairs Secretary David Shulkin. The president just tweeted: "I am pleased to announce that I intend to nominate highly-respected Admiral Ronny L. Jackson, M.D., as the new secretary of Veterans Affairs. In the interim, Honorable Mike Wilkie of DOD will serve as acting secretary. I'm thankful for Dr. David Shulkin's service to our country and to our great veterans!" Jesse, does this come as a shock or surprise?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It did not, because we've been hearing a lot about this for the last month or so. This was an Obama holdover, Shulkin. And we all know what happened at the V.A. under President Obama, where they had these long waiting lines, and bureaucrats were giving bonuses for service that they did not provide, while people died waiting for care that they never received. So this guy was brought in and, apparently, was supposed to have cleaned things up. I don't know how effective he was in cleaning that up. The president campaigned on taking care of the veterans and was very proud to sign a new V.A. accountability bill, where it was more easy to fire people who were underperforming. And that's a good thing. But I think there were some travel issues with him. He might have run afoul of the administration on some ethical issues with respect to that. And he had to go. The president is not going to keep some guy at that agency that's not 100 percent behind the veterans and can't afford to allow any sort of perception out there that the president is not taking care of the vets that he so deeply values. And we know the new guy is the star of that "Trump is in perfect mental and physical health" press conference. And I think I speak for the table. We all really like and admire that guy.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: We really do. And I very good about your chances and my chances to live a long and healthy life with a very similar meal and diet plan.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's right. Put me on the treadmill.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I have a feeling that maybe he's asking Ronny Jackson to head over to V.A. because he had instituted new diet rules at the White House. It's like "I know how to fix this. Send him to V.A." Ronny Jackson is an amazing medical doctor. He was well-respected by many administrations. He's been there, I think, for three or four of the last presidencies. And he also -- I think it's very important for President Trump, and what you see as he heads into the second phase of his presidency, on a personnel level, is that he really wants to have people there that he personally trusts. And he really knows this doctor very well now and trusts him and knows that Dr. Jackson will do a great job taking care of the veterans. And the other thing is, what's really strange, is all these weird rumors about the political appointees at the V.A. trying to usurp the secretary and a lot of the crazy things going on, barricading himself in the office. But as a public servant, I think that he has done a decent job and now will move on. And it's good to have new blood at the V.A.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: All right. There you go. OK, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: [groans]

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: All right, skipping Greg.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Skip.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Trump's shaking more cabinets than an IKEA truck driver.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Ooh.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: That's all you have?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I've got nothing. I guess Pete Hegseth is going --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: So do we.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: -- to be free from my show this weekend. Pete, gotcha. Always the bridesmaid.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wow.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Moving on. Even the control room is mad at you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Wouldn't be the first time.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I love Pete. I love Pete. Glad to have him here.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I know the president is having trouble hiring a lawyer, but has it occurred to any of you that mister -- Dr. Jackson has no background in handling a bureaucracy or reform?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Maybe that's good.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, gee, so maybe he hire -- he hires somebody who knows -- he knows personally. And maybe it -- I don't know. Maybe it's a payoff for that good health --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Come on. Oh, my God. Quid pro quo for this?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: He already has -- no, no, no. He had someone in who had experience dealing with bureaucracies and management, Shulkin, and that didn't work out so well.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Just be glad it's not the other personal doctor from before.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: What do you mean?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Remember during the campaign?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OH, that guy, the guy here in New York? That was -- that guy was something.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I liked that guy.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Everybody widely admires and respects him. He's going to do a fantastic job.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, no, no. He's wonderful.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: He's in touch with the veterans. He has served.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: How do you know that?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I think it's very good. Because I --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: He was in the military.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I know about him. I have actually prepared and know about him, and he's fantastic.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I don't know --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: How did you prepare and know about him?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Because I heard that his name was under consideration.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But do you really think this guy --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I was wondering if it was going to be mm-mm or mm-mm.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: In a normal administration -- because you know, let's admit, we're not in normal today. You know? But let's just say, in a normal administration, they just bring in the guy who happens to be the president's doctor with no background in this area, no experience, no relationships, no networks.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, the Senate will have a chance to bring it up.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He was also Obama's doctor, so there you go.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, yes, yes. No, no.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: He was very good, apparently, right, when he was under Obama? But now he's not, because he's President Trump's doctor?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, no, no. He's a good guy.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The guy that was, like, killing everybody in wait lines had tons of bureaucratic experience.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: That's what I would have said, yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: The guy that was killing everybody?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Remember all the veterans that died in the wait lines?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Before Shulkin. That was before Shulkin.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I know. And that guy was the administrator of all these hospitals.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: The hospitals had trouble. But let me tell you, this again is overblown. Veterans have a high opinion of the Veterans Administration's medical services.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's true.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But again, it gets into the media, and you say, "Oh, it's terrible. It's terrible." They just want better service. And they deserve better.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: A lot of the veterans I know, they're not so psyched on it. They think they get sent home with a bag of pills and become addicted to the prescription medication. And opioids.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: There is an argument about whether or not they would get better treatment. Some people say privatize it, send them out to regular -- but they don't want it. Everybody thinks they get better service from the Veterans Administration. But I'm all for it. I hope it works. I'm just saying would you really hire somebody with no experience?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I don't know. It's like an echo in here.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Pete was my guy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He was your guy.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I know. All right. You've got to knock it off. You've got to knock it off. I don't want to hear another word from you for literally the next, like, five minutes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Am I grounded?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Zip it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Skip.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Directly ahead -- permanent -- the surprising activity that may help you live longer. Eat burgers. Details next.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Hey, some good news for music lovers. You can stop feeling guilty about all that money you spent on concert tickets. A new study says watching live music may actually help you live longer. Researchers at Goldsmiths University in London have found 20 minutes at a concert, that's better for you and for your well-being then yoga or walking your dog.
